bibl.title: Letter from Francisco Dominguez Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, January 20, 1942

div1.p: Roldan informs Hench that he cannot find the Finlay speech, from 1900, but will continue to look for it. He refers Hench to a reprint of an 1881 Finlay speech.

div1.head: Letter from Francisco Dominguez Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, January 20, 1942
div1.opener:
MENDOZA Y GUTIERREZ
MARIANAO
HABANA
January 20, 1942.
Mr. P. S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of January 6, 1942, here is the information I can gi-
ve you.

We have no document referring to the speech Finlay made on December 22, 1900,
at the banquet I presided over with General Leonard Wood, General Governor of Cuba,
but it should be in the collection of books published by General Wood during his
government in Cuba. These books should be at the National Archives, and to that
effect I have written to the Director, who was my companion during our Independence
War; if it exists, he will send me a copy of Finlay's speech, and I will forward it
to you. All the documents of the American Intervention were taken away by the Mis-
sion when it left Cuba independent.

In case you are interested in the work Finlay read to The Academy on August 14,
1881, you will find it in English in the “Medical Classics” of February 1938. The
whole number is dedicated to Finlay, and the selections were made by Dr. Emerson
Crossby Kelly, of the Surgery Department, at the Albany Medical College. Dr. Kelly
and I exchanged several letters, and my answer to him you will find in the “Anales
de la Academia de Ciencias Médicas, Físicas y Naturales de la Habana”, 1938, in the
number of the “Extraordinary Session” (Session Extraordinaria) which was held to
welcome me on my return from Europe.

I shall be pleased to give you any other information you desire. I suppose
you have received the last pamphlet I sent you in answer to your previous letter
about the U.S. Commission.

It is a pity that a purely scientific question should be taken over by non-
professional men who give their opinion on the greatest scientific discovery of
America.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Dr. Francisco Dominguez.
Foreign Associate Member
of the
Paris Medical Academy. FD/mld
